urn:contentItem:6F0W-6KB3-RSCS-H2WY-00000-00Life persists inside the forbidden zone2025-01-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisOPINIONLettersPg. 18Life persists inside the forbidden zoneAn AGE Ago: 1994

We revisit The Age's January 29, 1994, report on the aftermath of the Chernobyl nuclear explosion.

It is snowing in the Ukraine and the road to Chernobyl, 130 kilometres north of the capital, Kiev, is pristine white.

Fields and tall forests of pine and oak slide past on either side as we slow to pass a horse and haycart, driven by two peasants clad in thick, black coats to keep out the cold.

It could be a rural scene from a century ago, or even just 10 years ago, when this region was the bread basket of the former Soviet Union.

But life has changed dramatically here ever since reactor number four at the Chernobyl nuclear power station exploded in the first hours of 26 April 1986, showering caesium 137 and other radioactive fallout over central Europe, Scandinavia and Britain.

Now, no one dares eat the fruit on the trees or the fish in the streams around Chernobyl and the countryside has become a wasteland, a land of ghost towns and deserted farms.

Officially it is called the "Exclusion Zone" - a no-go area extending in a 30-kilometre circle around the Chernobyl nuclear power station, near the border with Byelorussia.

But to everyone in the Ukraine, it's known simply as "the zone". It is a place of warped humor and knowing smiles, where alcohol is banned but vodka appears from under the table the moment guests or visitors arrive.

With the vodka come the wry jokes about radiation. Take a full bottle of vodka and follow each shot with a red wine chaser. When the vodka bottle is empty you won't need to worry about radiation.

The Russians call the zone "the land of alienation". The Ukrainians call the people who have worked in it "the liquidators". In both countries, the word "sarcophagus" now refers to only one thing - the zone's epicentre, the concrete and metal coffin of Chernobyl's reactor number four.

The scientists say no one will ever live in the zone again, though criminals and outlaws are said to roam its "forbidden forests". About 800 former residents have also moved back to their villages inside the zone, defying repeated attempts by guards to drive them away.

We arrive at the 30-kilometre gate, where the zone begins, and are told we must transfer to an approved vehicle. As a precaution against contamination, there are two types. One is allowed to travel inside the 30-kilometre zone but not into the 10-kilometre inner zone around the reactor. The other can travel inside both zones, but can never leave the 30-kilometre perimeter.

Chernobyl was once a pretty village of farm cottages and fruit trees. Now it is overgrown and abandoned, except for a few hundred people who travel here daily to work in administration. It lies at the end of a narrow road lined with forests, flanked by signs warning against throwing cigarette butts and matches out the window. The trees hold so much radiation, mainly in their bark, that authorities fear any forest fire would send clouds of radiation into the atmosphere. In the village's central square stands a large statue of Lenin.

We pass nuclear reactors five and six which were under construction at the time of the explosion. Everything has been left as it was - cranes hang motionless over the unfinished reactor towers. Trucks, buses, helicopters and building materials lie abandoned by the road.

No one dares touch them.

urn:contentItem:6DDX-4DD1-JD34-V0S5-00000-00Summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeks2024-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 6Summer fire restrictions to begin in less than two weeksMonique Patterson

The Fire Danger Period for Warrnambool will begin later this month.

The period will officially begin on November 25, 2024, and end on May 1, 2025.

Restrictions will also come into force on the same date for Corangamite, Moyne, Glenelg and Southern Grampians shires. The restrictions mean no open fires can be lit in any municipality without a permit. In October, the Australasian Fire And Emergency Services Authorities Council (AFAC) forecast an above average fire season for the region.

Forest Fire Management Victoria far south-west district manager Sheree Mirtschin urged residents to be prepared.

"The forecast for an above-average fire season for the far south-west highlights the importance of taking a year-round approach to preparing for summer bushfires," Ms Mirtschin said.

Fire Danger Period restrictions A written permit is required to burn off grass, undergrowth, weeds or other vegetation during the FDP. You can apply for a permit at firepermits.vic.gov.au. It can also be issued by the Municipal Fire Prevention Officer or the CFA District Office. Lighting fires in the open without a permit can bring a penalty of more than $21,800 and/or 12 months imprisonment. Residents and visitors to the region can Download the VicEmergency app and keep an eye on the CFA website for further information about the Fire Danger Period and Total Fire Ban days.

urn:contentItem:6F0N-P753-RVBC-S3JF-00000-00Farmers prepare to fight new Grampians fire as rest of national park ignites2025-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisFarmers prepare to fight new Grampians fire as rest of national park ignitesPetra Oates Barry Murphy

Five new fires ignited on Monday in the Grampians National Park.

West Grampians farmers are preparing to defend their properties as five new fires were ignited by lightning strikes on Monday evening.

The new blazes come just three weeks after the east Grampians fire was contained.

Between 5-6pm on Monday, three fires started in the north-west part of the Grampians, while two more caught in the south-west part of the Grampians.

All five of the newly ignited fires are located in previously unburnt parts of the Grampians National Park that were unaffected by the other Grampians fire this season .

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the five new fires were located in "particularly remote and inaccessible areas".

"Those fires will continue to grow and they will become what we would describe as a campaign fire," Mr Hardman said.

"Those fires in the southern part of the Grampians will progress and eventually meet up with those fires in the northern parts of the Grampians."

He said he wanted to create an expectation that these fires "will be in play for some time".

Right now the vast majority of the Grampians National Park is closed and the communities most at risk include Wartook and Halls Gap.

Mr Hardman said at this stage the Halls Gap community had not been evacuated but access into Halls Gap had been restricted.

"The weather for the next few days is southerly and south-westerly winds that will continue to push those fires into unburnt country on Saturday," he said.

The recently contained Yarram Gap fire in the Grampians burned around one-third of the Grampians National Park, covering 76,000 hectares, and took 21 days to contain .

Victorian Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said these new fires would continue to grow in size and burn for some time.

"They will be incredibly challenging for firefighters to contain," Mr Nugent said.

Brimpaen mixed farmers Cameron and Sandra McDonald were busy preparing on Tuesday as the latest wave of bushfire raged near.

With the blaze currently just 1km from the farm's boundary, the couple expected it to reach their 400ha property in a matter of hours.

Mr Cameron was extremely frustrated with the management of the fire by authorities since it started on Monday afternoon, and blamed them for not acting quickly enough.

"They should have had water bombers on this as soon as they saw a puff of smoke," he said.

"I want to know why not?

"They're incompetent.

"It's too late when it's well and truly got going."

It was the seventh big fire to hit the property in 40 years and Mr Cameron said it would make anyone strongly consider the feasibility of living at the national park's boundary.

The farm was completely burnt out in 2014 with significant damage to pasture and fences but luckily, no stock losses.

Mr Cameron said the couple, supported by family and friends, were ready to fight the fire and had all their own trucks, sprinklers and equipment.

"We're actually experts in disaster management now," he said.

Ricky Luhrs, Mooralla, said while the new bushfire was currently some distance from his farm of 8000 Merino ewes, he was nervous.

Mr Luhrs said easterly winds to come this weekend, along with the fire spotting, could threaten the area.

"It might get to us by the weekend," he said.

"It has rung alarm bells and we'll be moving sheep closer to the yards and setting up containment pens."

The last fire in the Grampians was only recently contained in early January after burning across the eastern part of the national park for 21 days. Picture supplied

urn:contentItem:6F0P-W323-RRK3-B4K5-00000-00VIC:Winds, terrain could merge national park bushfires2025-01-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVIC:Winds, terrain could merge national park bushfiresHORSHAM, VICTORIA Jan 29

  Raging bushfires at either end of a blaze-ravaged national park could merge as crews grapple with the rugged terrain and southerly winds.
   With locals in the northwest Victoria town of Dimboola returning home after a fast-moving bushfire destroyed property, authorities are shifting their focus to two out-of-control blazes in the popular Grampians National Park.


   The fire to the southwest of the park has grown to 4500 hectares and is threatening isolated properties and camp grounds.
   Residents and holidaymakers in the area were urged to leave late on Tuesday, with roads leading to Halls Gap still open.
   State Control Centre spokesperson Luke Heagerty said it grew considerably in the past 24 hours and was sending smoke towards the regional centre of Horsham and into NSW.
   Further north, a collection of smaller fires, ranging from 150ha to 300ha, are burning in the Wallaby Rocks area near Zumsteins.
   Firefighters are working on protecting private farmland next to the park ahead of forecast warmer, windier weather later in the week and into next week.
   "Once the fire has reached the end of the park and it's in more open grassland, we can have fire crews there waiting to extinguish and to also establish some containment lines if possible," he told AAP on Wednesday morning.
   It took 21 days to bring blazes in the Grampians, sparked on December 17, under control.
   Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said the latest blazes could burn for weeks, while Mr Heagerty conceded they could join.
   "Where we've got the right combination of wind and where we've not been able to establish containment lines or use some other strategies to slow the spread of the fire, that is a possibility," he told AAP.
   "We really don't want to use that as an assumption that that will happen but the reality that we're dealing with in the Grampians National Park is that it's very difficult to get crews in to the area between those two groups of fires."
   It was a wind change that left locals in Dimboola, near the South Australian border, just 30 minutes to pack up their lives and evacuate over fears the town was under threat.
   The blaze was sparked by dry lightning, one of 10,000-odd strikes that hit the ground in the state on Monday, and has grown to almost 70,000ha.
   "It all sort of hit in a two hour period, so quite a distance away, obviously you see the plumes," cattle owner Quentin Barrett told AAP.
   "We thought we're good, we thought it might miss us, but then the wind just changed and everything just ran."
   A wedding venue and two farm houses were destroyed in the Dimboola fire, which is not yet controlled but has been downgraded to watch and act with locals allowed to go home.
   Mr Barrett lost three cattle when flames jumped across a river at the back of his brother's property and tore through fences.
   "One fence line could cost upwards of $10,000 to $20,000 for a stretch, and there's three of those," he said.
   "We unfortunately weren't insured."
   Dimboola resident Bree Myers and seven-year-old daughter Indie Francis hung a sheet painted with the words "thank you fireys" outside their house the moment they returned.
   "We were just really worried, seriously worried, that we'd come back to nothing," Ms Myers said.
   "It's the least we could do, just so they know that we appreciate it."

urn:contentItem:6DK5-J2C1-JD34-V198-00000-00Helicopters ready for fires2024-12-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 9Helicopters ready for firesGeorgina Sebar

Bendigo's air attack firefighting team are now equipped with a livestreaming camera to help firefighters back on the ground make the best decisions during this year's bushfire season.

The two helicopters, Helitak 335 and Firebird 305, work in tandem to drop up to 3500 litres of water during central Victoria's bushfire season.

Luke Waterson, an air attack supervisor with the CFA, said Bendigo's natural terrain meant Helitak and Firebird were one of the busiest teams in the state.

"There's a lot of forest, there's obviously a lot of grassland to the north and west and the undulating hills makes the access and egress for a lot of our crews a little bit more difficult," Mr Waterson said.

The helicopters are managed by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA.

"So we'll be here, every day until after early March, making sure that if there is a fire that we can respond quickly and keep fires small," Mr Waterson said.

The National Council for fire and emergency services has released its Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Summer 2024, which shows large areas of the western half of Victoria as having an increased risk of fire.

The two helicopters work as a team, with Helitak carrying the water and Firebird coordinating.

They operate on a Predetermined Dispatch (PDD) scheme, which means that once certain environmental factors are triggered over the fire danger period, the helicopters respond in the same way as a truck.

PDD was first trialed in Bendigo in 2012 after the Royal Commission into the Black Saturday bushfires recommended a way to send air attack helicopters without requiring a request be put through from an incident controller or the state duty officer.

Without this requirement, the firebombers are able to reach fire sites more quickly than ground crews, preventing the flames from spreading.

There are now more than 50 firefighting helicopters across Victoria working on the PDD system.

urn:contentItem:6DV7-4SY3-SC42-64JC-00000-00Warnings dialled back in Otways as firefighters move quickly on bushfire2025-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisWarnings dialled back in Otways as firefighters move quickly on bushfireAngus Delaney

Firefighters have contained a bushfire which prompted evacuations and left campers stranded in remote parts of the Otways.

Firefighters have contained a bushfire which prompted evacuations and left campers stranded in remote parts of the Otways, in Victoria's south-west.

Campers were warned to immediately evacuate in the early hours of Wednesday morning, and about 7am they were told to shelter as it was too late to leave. By 8.14am, authorities had downgraded warnings, imposing a watch and act message for the Cape Otway area and noting that conditions are changing.

A small pocket on the cape's west coast, including the Blanket Bay campground, is not safe to return to, according to authorities. About 100 campers were stranded in the remote campground when the fire obscured any escape routes.

Meanwhile, 22 hikers on the Great Ocean Road walk were transported to the Cape Otway Lightstation and people at other campsites were evacuated to nearby Apollo Bay.

Forest Fire Management Victoria chief fire officer Chris Hardman said everyone in the area was safe.

"The crews are working really hard and are going to contain the fire ... and hopefully get on top of this really quickly," he told 3AW.

"But it is dynamic and things can change ... Mother Nature can sometimes throw a curveball at us."

Frank Fotinas from campground Bimbi Park said he was alerted to the fire about 2am on Wednesday. By 3am, the message was to evacuate.

"The guests were fantastic. I mean we had everyone out in under an hour, which was just super," Fotinas said.

"The only thing is the easterly winds and they're coming directly to us. That's the thing that we're bit concerned about.

"Me and my son and a couple of our neighbours are here at Bimbi Park ... we won't leave until, sort of until the last minute."

A watch-and-act message is in place for Glenaire, Hordern Vale and Cape Otway, north of the area covered by the emergency warning.

An evacuation centre has been established at the Apollo Bay Community Centre. A sunny 24-degree day is forecast for Cape Otway on Wednesday.

The developments come after the bushfire in the Grampians National Park was contained on Monday. The blaze scorched more than 76,000 hectares, destroying four homes and 40 outbuildings in surrounding towns.

CFA incident controller Peter West said: "Coinciding with what is typically the busiest season for tourism in the area, the fire has resulted in considerable hardships and financial losses for local businesses and communities."

On Wednesday, Halls Gap, a popular tourist town at the foot of the Grampians, will reopen to visitors from 10am. Unaffected parts of the national park will reopen from 9am on Friday.

urn:contentItem:6DV9-V4X3-RRSR-Y06C-00000-00Dry soil drives up fire risk2025-01-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 4Dry soil drives up fire riskPeter Hunt

Soil moisture levels have plummeted across western and southern Victoria, drying out grassland and forests, exacerbating the risk of major bushfires.

The Keetch-Byram Drought Index, which was developed by the US Forestry Service and used by the Australian Bureau of Meteorology to assess the risk of fire, has soared to 103 around Stawell and 133 in Horsham.

Retired Monash University bushfire scientist David Packham said "things get serious once the index gets above 100".

The drought index is based on how much rain is needed to saturate the soil at each location, to bring it back to field capacity, factoring in both past local rainfall and evaporation.

CFA volunteers fighting the Grampians inferno have already reported conditions are so dry that fire is racing across paddocks where there is hardly any fuel.

Stawell farmer and CFA captain Malcolm Nicholson said fire just whipped across paddocks that crews thought were defendable, given the lack of fuel, leaving just smoking cow pats behind. "We've had just 130mm for the growing season (April-October)," Mr Nicholson said. "Normally we get 250mm to 300mm." He said the probe on his property, which measures moisture levels 20cm under the pasture, had been sitting "in the red" since winter.

The impact of the long dry is most clearly seen in the BoM's latest deep-layer soil moisture map, showing levels are "very much below average" in the layer 1m to 6m below the surface and in some areas are at levels only seen once in 100 years.

The CFA's latest curing map also shows most of the state paddocks are completely dried off, due to dry soils and rising summer temperatures.

Dunkeld agricultural scientist Peter Flinn said the district faced its driest year since 2006, when the Mount Lubra fire burnt out 127,000ha of the Grampians, equal to 47 per cent of the national park, with the loss of three lives, 41 houses, 65,598 livestock, plus fencing and 231 farm sheds and other out buildings.

Mr Flinn said history was repeating itself, because not enough was being done to reduce fuel loads: "It's very frustrating".

As president of the Howitt Society, Mr Flinn said the group has "pushed as hard as hell to get more fuel reduction burns done", but "we're up against the green lobbyists in Melbourne".

Early last year the Save Our Strathbogie Forest Group took legal action to try to halt fuel reduction burns, arguing Forest Fire Management Victoria should have to gain federal approval under the Environment Protection and Biodiversity Conservation Act before it lit up any bushland. At the time SOSF president Bertram Lobert argued pres-crib-ed burns should be stopped because they destroyed tree hollows that were home to the Strathbogie Forests' Southern Greater Glider population.

urn:contentItem:6DRV-8JT3-RS6S-F226-00000-00250 lightning strikes spark more fires2024-12-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexis250 lightning strikes spark more fires

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Peter Hunt and David Johnston

Lightning strikes have started "multiple" fires in Victoria's North East as cooler weather brings relief to CFA crews fighting spot fires breaking out the Grampians.

Forest Fire Management Victoria crews have descended on the Whitfield, Cheshunt and Tatong areas south of Wangaratta on the fresh outbreaks, which at this stage are contained to relatively small areas.

Three of the six small fires have been contained.

Rappel firefighters based at Ovens were deployed on Friday, along with 40 forest firefighters, dozers and firebombing aircraft.

Crews' initial focus will be constructing containment lines around the fires ahead of rising temperatures forecast from Monday.

Three of the six small fires have been contained.

FFMV Ovens district manager Jarrod Hayse said the cool change accompanied by a band of dry lightning from Benalla through to Dargo hit the region early Friday.

"All of them are difficult to access fires," he said.

"The issue is the underlying dryness.

"Even though we've got milder temperatures today the fuel is still dry.

"We've had over 12 months of very dry conditions."

About 250 lightning strikes were detected across the state when the cool change came through.

Meanwhile back at the Grampians Stawell CFA captain and farmer Malcolm Nicholson said local crews were resting up as relief teams were brought in from further afield on Friday.

"This is the eleventh day of this shit show," he said.

While cooler conditions have brought relief, Mr Nicholson said the Pomonal community was still on edge, given it's the second time this year they have faced a major bushfire.

Further south the Stawell group of brigades spent much of yesterday fighting a finger of fire that whipped out of the Grampians on the back of embers carried out of the forest on gusty westerly winds.

"It travelled at about 2.5 to 3 km/h through the grass, running east towards Willaura," he said.

Emergency Management Commissioner Rick Nugent said all emergency warnings had now been downgraded to watch and act, with residents from Pomonal, Moyston and Willaura likely to be given the all clear to return home on Friday afternoon.

Commissioner Nugent said the forecast was for stable weather for the next week, but warned the Grampians fire was likely to burn for weeks.

Deputy Premier Ben Carroll said the Allan Government had made personal hardship grants of $340 per child and $680 per adult available.

urn:contentItem:6DJY-JWB1-F0J6-J101-00000-00Choppers livestream bushfires to help firefighters build plan of attack2024-12-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisChoppers livestream bushfires to help firefighters build plan of attackGeorgina Sebar

Bendigo's air attack firefighting team are now equipped with a livestreaming camera to help firefighters back on the ground make the best decisions during this year's bushfire season.

The two helicopters, Helitak 335 and Firebird 305, work in tandem to drop up to 3500 litres of water during central Victoria's bushfire season.

Luke Waterson, an air attack supervisor with the CFA, said Bendigo's natural terrain meant Helitak and Firebird were one of the busiest teams in the state.

"There's a lot of forest, there's obviously a lot of grassland to the north and west and the undulating hills makes the access and egress for a lot of our crews a little bit more difficult," Mr Waterson said.

The helicopters are managed by Forest Fire Management Victoria and the CFA.

"So we'll be here, every day until after early March, making sure that if there is a fire that we can respond quickly and keep fires small," Mr Waterson said.

The National Council for fire and emergency services has released its Seasonal Bushfire Outlook for Summer 2024, which shows large areas of the western half of Victoria as having an increased risk of fire.

Predetermined Dispatch The two helicopters work as a team, with Helitak carrying the water and Firebird coordinating.

They operate on a Predetermined Dispatch (PDD) scheme, which means that once certain environmental factors are triggered over the fire danger period, the helicopters respond in the same way as a truck.

PDD was first trialed in Bendigo in 2012 after the Royal Commission into the Black Saturday bushfires recommended a way to send air attack helicopters without requiring a request be put through from an incident controller or the state duty officer.

Without this requirement, the firebombers are able to reach fire sites more quickly than ground crews, preventing the flames from spreading.

There are now more than 50 firefighting helicopters across Victoria working on the PDD system.

urn:contentItem:6DP4-WXD3-S2DF-21J4-00000-00Vernon looks back at time in tower2024-12-20T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisNEWS4Vernon looks back at time in tower

Three decades of smoke spotting for veteran Lookout Observer

From page 1

"You still need people on the ground," he said.

In his three decades on the job, technology has been the most significant change he has seen in fire prevention and management.

"It has advanced in leaps and bounds," he said. "This is a good thing; it can help. Even improving our computers and systems makes the job more effective.

"When I started this job, we weren't using aircraft; it was a new concept then, but their introduction has meant crews get to fires quicker and to places you can't reach by land. The aircraft is undoubtedly easier and faster."

While he is talking, he is continually scanning the horizon.

"Over there is Mt William and Halls Gap," he said. "From up here, you get an appreciation for the area, but seeing it from the air is even more incredible."

Before watching the world from his advantage point, Mr Collings volunteered with the CFA for 50 years and worked at Best Wines.

An accident during a fire, which injured both wrists, meant he couldn't continue working actively on the ground.

Working in the industry as a Fire Lookout Observer was an excellent opportunity for him to continue what he loved doing: helping keep the community safe.

The tower at Stawell was opened in 1964 and upgraded in 1997 with an official opening by the Police and Emergency Services minister, Bill McGrath on September 9, 1997,

Federal Emergency Management Minister Senator Jenny McAllister said new technology has the potential to transform disaster preparation and response.

"The early bushfire technology deployed in this trial could help authorities detect and suppress bushfires before they impact communities," she said.

Forest Fire Management Victoria is conducting the trial, which is funded by the government's Disaster Ready Fund.

The software and cameras will support the work of FFMVic's Fire Lookout Observers, who work across 64 fire lookouts - especially at times when lookouts aren't staffed after hours or due to health and safety concerns such as operating or climbing in the dark and extreme weather conditions.

The view from the fire tower in Stawell overlooking the town towards the Grampians covered in a haze. Picture by Sheryl Lowe

urn:contentItem:6DV0-BTG3-RTNH-64WX-00000-00Bushfire contained, but Grampians National Park remains closed to visitors2025-01-07T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisBushfire contained, but Grampians National Park remains closed to visitorsBen Fraser

FFMVic declared the 76,7720-hectare Grampians bushfire contained.

With almost half an inch of rain falling overnight, Forest Fire Management Victoria issued a welcome piece of advice.

On January 6, almost three weeks after the blaze ignited about 22km north of Dunkeld, FFMVic declared the 76,7720-hectare Grampians National Park bushfire contained.

Incident Controller Peter West said the announcement was a welcome milestone.

"This fire represents a significant environmental and social incident and one that deeply affects people connected to the national park, including Traditional Owners, tourism operators and visitors," he said.

"Coinciding with what is typically the busiest season for tourism in the area, the fire has resulted in considerable hardships and financial losses for local businesses and communities.

"Declaring the fire contained allows us to begin the process of reopening Halls Gap and areas of the national park.

Mr West said firefighters would monitor and patrol the fire, which could still take a number of weeks.

"It is likely we will still see smoke and small flare-ups in the area, but we will continue to be present to deal with these when and as they arise," he said.

"I want to thank the community and the public for their remarkable patience during our battle with this fire.

"We understand that many plans had to be altered and that the resulting inconvenience has had a significant impact on daily life and significant events such as Christmas."

The news comes as 12.8mm of rain fell overnight, mostly between 6-9am.

However, the national park remains off-limits to most states as emergency services assess the damage.

Only Halls Gap residents can return to their properties via Traffic Management Points. Proof of address will be required.

Halls Gap business operators are invited to a forum from 1-12pm on Tuesday, January 7, at the Halls Hap Centenary Hall; a whole community forum will follow at 2pm.

Authorities are planning to reopen Halls Gap to businesses and visitors later in the week; however, an exact date has not been confirmed.

The fire claimed four homes in Moyston and Mafeking, and 40 outbuildings in Moyston, Willaura, Willaura North, Mafeking, Pomonal, Glenthompson and Mirranatwa.

Initial surveying shows livestock losses included 775 sheep, a horse, one beef cattle and 1285 beehives.

On December 29, 2024, Prime Minister Anthony Albanese announced in Horsham that bushfire-hit workers and sole traders can apply for up to 13 weeks of income support.

The allowance has been made available alongside other supports, including disaster assistance for each council and a one-off payment of $680 per adult and $340 per child up to a maximum of $2380 per eligible family to help cover essentials such as food, clothing, medication and accommodation.

An aerial view of the Grampians National Park bushfire aftermath. Picture supplied

urn:contentItem:6F26-NTF3-RXT2-M3G6-00000-00Victoria's volunteer firefighting force shrinks to new low2025-02-04T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T07:44:20ZLexisNexisVictoria's volunteer firefighting force shrinks to new low

Document links may not lead to an active page. Page maintenance is at the discretion of the publisher.

Alex White

Victoria's volunteer firefighting force has shrunk to a new low while the bill for paid staff soars and property owners are hit with skyrocketing levies to pay for the state's fire services.

New figures released in the Productivity Commission's government services report revealed that as of June 2024 Victoria had just 28,906 operational volunteers, down from 36,823 when the Labor government first came to power in 2014.

The figure is now less than half of the NSW's volunteer force, which sat at 67,569.

The reports released on Tuesday - which showed a snapshot of emergency management across the country - revealed that Victoria had the most paid firefighters, who were now costing the state a whopping $1.23bn a year in employee costs - the highest salary bill in the country and more than $230m a year more than the NSW service.

It's more than double the $600m the state's fire service cost to run in 2014-15.

The reports also showed that Victorian property owners were bearing the brunt of the cost with Victoria having the highest levies on property owners who dished out $839.5m - higher than Queensland which took $659 million in property levies.

The financial hit will also only get harder for Victorian homeowners with the Allan government revealing it will replace the Fire Services Property Levy with a new Emergency Services and Volunteers Fund (ESVF) from July 1, 2025.

The new levy would support more agencies including VICSES, Triple Zero Victoria, the State Control Centre, Emergency Management Victoria, Emergency Recovery Victoria and Forest Fire Management Victoria, in addition to the CFA and Fire Rescue Victoria, but its not yet clear how much will be passed on directly to the fore services.

The budget update revealed the new levy, which appears on homeowner's rates notices, will now rake in $6.27bn over the next five years, including a whopping $1.8bn in 2027-28.

CFA Chief Officer Jason Heffernan said "Volunteer numbers will always fluctuate over time for a variety of reasons".

"CFA recognises the current trend and emerging research that a younger generation is moving away from traditional forms of volunteering and are looking for more flexible, short duration and dynamic volunteer experiences.

"That is why CFA is in the process of renewing our operating model."

Opposition spokesman for emergency services Danny O'Brien said: "These figures show that Victorians are paying more for fire services and actually getting less.

"Ten years of Labor disrespecting our CFA volunteers has seen a trend of numbers dropping off - from 35,000 operational volunteers when Labor came to office to now less than 29,000. "That's less people to protect Victorians in times of emergency and yet we're paying more than other states for the privilege.

"Labor can't manage money, can't manage our fire services and it's Victorians who are paying the price."

In recent years, Victoria's fire services have experienced significant changes.

Paid firefighters were transitioned out of the CFA and integrated into Fire Rescue Victoria, which replaced the Metropolitan Fire Brigade, transforming the CFA into an entirely volunteer-based organisation.

The Productivity Commission's report also showed fire crews in Victoria were called to 93,729 incidents last year.

More than 5700 of these were structural fires - and Victoria had one of the fastest response time in the country - 4434 were landscape fires, 2301 were road incidents and 15,657 were system initiated false alarms.

A state government spokesman said "our volunteers put their lives on the line every day to protect Victorians and we are incredibly grateful for the work they do".

"We know we need to support our volunteers to continuing growing the pool - that's why we are delivering more resources, including brand new trucks fitted with the latest technology, new and upgraded stations, and advanced training opportunities, the spokesperson said.

"Victoria is one of the most fire prone areas and we have some of the most highly skilled paid firefighters and volunteers in the nation - the community should rest assured that they are well protected in a bushfire emergency no matter where they live."
